Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: CAS: Recyclable Polystyrene-Substitutes through On-demand Depolymerization
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The overall goal of this research is to establish recyclable thermoplastics that are based on polystyrene-substitute materials since plastics made of polystyrene itself are not commonly recycled. Polymers are an essential material class used in nearly all modern products. However, most of the used polymer products are landfilled, improperly discarded, or incinerated and thus have environmental consequences. The high-cost problem of polymer recycling suggests the desirability to develop new polymers with low-cost and facile recyclability without compromising physical properties needed for practical applications. This research aims to establish a new class of recyclable thermoplastics that can effectively substitute polystyrene. Polystyrene is one of the largest produced thermoplastic polymers used as a key component for numerous commodity and specialty applications. However, polystyrene has been barely recycled due to high cost. The proposed research will replace non-recyclable polystyrene with new high-performance thermoplastics that can be recycled from used products at low cost. This research will significantly benefit society by establishing polystyrene-substituting recyclable thermoplastics that could remedy the environmental problems caused by polystyrene wastes. The planned work also includes educational activities for K-12 and undergraduate students to enhance their exposure and understanding of STEM fields with a focus on polymers and materials structures.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The planned research aims to establish and study recyclable thermoplastic polymers as polystyrene substitutes through implementing low-cost and facile depolymerizability. The depolymerizability will be achieved by copolymerizing monomer with a low-ceiling temperature and other monomer that controls the properties of polymers. A library of recyclable copolymers will be synthesized, depolymerization characteristics of the polymer library will be studied, and optical and viscoelastic properties of the copolymers will be characterized for evaluation of the new polymers as polystyrene substitutes and beyond. These efforts will establish the correlations between the chemical composition of the copolymers and the physical/depolymerization properties. The established correlations of recyclable copolymers will serve as the design criteria of polymers for target applications. The project will provide graduate and undergraduate students with broad research training on polymers ranging from synthesis to characterization and materials properties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Polystyrene is an important thermoplastic widely used for numerous applications, such as packaging, structural materials, and electronics components. However, the chemical and physical inertness of polystyrene makes its recycling difficult. This project aims to position polystyrene and relevant wastes as urban hydrocarbon ores for producing value-added chemical compounds using a simple but strong acid (figure 1). The major research outcomes of this project are i) elucidation of the chain degradation process of polystyrene by triflic acid, ii) design and synthesis of polystyrene substitute polymers by copolymerizing vinyl monomers with 1,1-diphenylethylene, which adds inherent acid-assisted upcyclability function, and iii) thermal and mechanical property characterizations of the 1,1-diphenylethylene copolymers as polystyrene substitutes and high-performance polymer materials.

The first achievement of this research is elucidating the chain conformation changes and their impacts during the acid-assisted chain-breaking process of polystyrene. In the upcycling of polymers, breaking chains is the first step to converting polymers into useful compounds, and understanding the changes in the chemical functional groups in polymer chains during the chemical upcycling process has been of primary interest. However, the importance of polymer chain conformations to the chain-breaking process accompanied by the functional group changes has not been recognized. This research documented how the polymer chain conformations change and when small molecular compounds are generated by acid during the degradation process. We observed that acid induces inter- or intra-chain polystyrene crosslinking depending on the acid concentration and molecular weight. Once the size of polystyrene chains reaches a limit size by intra-chain coupling, the chain rapidly breaks rather than reducing the size further. The initiation rate of the rapid chain breaking is observed slow, although once the chain breaking starts, the chain breaks into small compounds relatively fast.

The second achievement is synthesizing a library of poly(1,1-diphenylethylene) copolymers with enhanced upcyclability as polystyrene substitutes to document the thermal and mechanical properties of those copolymers. Compared to polystyrene, those poly(1,1-diphenylethylene) copolymers show rapid chain breaking into small value-added compounds such as benzene and diphenylethylene monomer even at a low triflic acid concentration in which polystyrene stays stable. The diphenyl groups facilitate the acid-assisted activation of the copolymer chain-breaking process.

The third achievement is the extensive thermal and mechanical property characterizations of the library of poly(1,1-diphenylethylene) copolymers with inherent acid-assisted upcycle capability. Thermal characterizations identify that the glass transition temperatures of poly(1,1-diphenylethylene) copolymers range from 101 °C, close to the glass transition temperature of polystyrene, to 194 °C, a glass transition temperature of engineering thermoplastics. Viscoelasticity characterizations also identify the entanglement molecular weights of poly(1,1-diphenylethylene) copolymers, which range from 17 kg/mol, close to the property of polystyrene, to 39 kg/mol, which makes a brittle polymer. Those characterization efforts identify that the poly(1,1-diphenylethylene) copolymers are versatile glassy polymers for target thermal and mechanical functions with designed upcycling capability.

Those research achievements demonstrate a new strategy of using functional comonomers to achieve the upcyclability of polystyrene and other polymers by using currently practiced polymeric material synthesis. Expanding this strategy is expected to other polymer classes. This project also resulted in strong educational outcomes. Two Ph.D. graduate students and eight undergraduate researchers were supported. The research outcomes have been disseminated five times at the national and local meetings. The principal investigator discussed the origin of the plastic pollution problem and potential solutions based on the research outcomes of this project for more than 70 high school students during the project period.
